title: How to Use Nasturtiums in Food

steps.headline: Harvest pesticide-free nasturtium flowers, buds, and leaves in the morning.
steps.description: Simply pinch them off with your fingers. The leaves and flowers tend to have a milder flavor when harvested in the cool of the morning, before the heat of the day stresses them. Nasturtiums grow well with minimal tending, so there’s no real need to use non-organic methods. If you find aphids nibbling on the leaves or flowers, simply spray them off with water. The entire plant is edible, though most people opt for the colorful flowers and buds. Young leaves are tender and delicious, while the stems and older leaves can be rather tough in texture and pungent in flavor.

steps.headline: Wash and dry your harvest, then chill it if you’re not using it immediately.
steps.description: Right after picking the flowers, leaves, and/or buds, rinse them under a stream of cool water and lay them on clean paper towels. Gently blot them dry with more clean paper towels. Unless you’re using them right away, place them in a plastic bag and refrigerate them. If you plan to eat the nasturtiums uncooked, use them within 24 hours for the best flavor and texture. If they’ll be cooked in a dish, you can store them in the fridge for up to 3 days.

steps.headline: Add nasturtium leaves and flowers to salads for both flavor and color.
steps.description: Nasturtiums have a peppery flavor reminiscent of watercress, so they make a great salad component. Simply toss in some of the tender leaves along with your other salad greens. Then, after you’ve dressed the salad, place some flower petals or whole flowers on top to make your salad look (and taste) fantastic! The flowers will start to wilt quickly, so serve the salad right away.

steps.headline: Use nasturtium flowers as a quick, easy, and tasty garnish.
steps.description: Try nestling a few whole flowers on top of some roasted veggies, pasta, or even a steak! Just remember to add the garnish right before serving so the flowers don’t wilt. It’s a great change of pace from parsley!

steps.headline: Try nasturtiums in both new recipes and old favorites.
steps.description: Nasturtiums can add a peppery touch to a wide range of recipes. For instance, finely tear or chop up some leaves, flowers, or both and add them to your next omelette, pasta dish, or stir fry about 1-2 minutes before the end of the cooking process. Or, because of the flavor similarity, try substituting nasturtium leaves in recipes that use watercress. Get creative with your own go-to recipes, or search online for recipes that feature nasturtiums.

steps.headline: Place a large pot of water over high heat on the stove.
steps.description: Put a lid on the pot to speed up the process of bringing the water to a boil.

steps.headline: Make an ice water bath in a large bowl.
steps.description: Fill a large bowl about half-full of cold water, then add roughly the number of ice cubes made by 2 ice cube trays. Do this while the pot is coming to a boil on the stove.

steps.headline: Boil 2 c (240 g) of nasturtium leaves for 10 seconds.
steps.description: Once the water comes to a boil, remove the lid and drop all the flowers in. Grab some tongs as you count to 10. The goal is to lightly blanch the delicate leaves, not fully cook them. Blanching further softens the leaves and preserves their vibrant green color in the finished dish.

steps.headline: Transfer the leaves directly to the ice water bath for 1-2 minutes.
steps.description: Use the tongs to move the flowers straight from the boiling water to the ice bath. After 1-2 minutes in the ice bath, transfer the flowers to some clean paper towels to dry. The ice water bath immediately stops the cooking process and helps the leaves stay bright green in color.

steps.headline: Mix the leaves, pine nuts, garlic, and oil in a blender.
steps.description: In addition to the blanched leaves, add 0.5 c (60 g) of toasted pine nuts, 4 cloves of garlic, and 8  fl oz (240 ml) of extra virgin olive oil to the blender cup. Blend the mixture until it’s smooth.

steps.headline: Fold in parmesan cheese and nasturtium stems to finish your pesto.
steps.description: Add 0.25 c (30 g) of freshly-grated parmesan and 0.5 c (60 g) of thinly-sliced nasturtium stems to the blended mixture. Fold them in gently. Serve your nasturtium pesto immediately for the best results. Refrigerate the pesto for up to 24 hours if needed.

steps.headline: Pick and clean 12 whole flowers right before making the dish.
steps.description: Pinch or cut the stem about 0.5 in (1.3 cm) behind each nasturtium flower so you can remove the flowers whole. Gently dunk each flower in cool, clean water, then very gently pat them dry with paper towels. Put them in the fridge until it’s time to stuff them. Stuff and serve the flowers within 8 hours; sooner is better, however. Pick, clean, and refrigerate enough young nasturtium leaves to cover your intended serving dish. These will be used for presentation purposes, although they are also edible.

steps.headline: Combine softened cream cheese with garlic and seasonings.
steps.description: Leave an 8 oz (120 g) package of cream cheese at room temperature for about 30 minutes to soften. Add it to a medium mixing bowl, then stir in 1 finely-minced garlic clove, 0.5 tbsp (7.5 g) of chives that you’ve finely chopped, and 1 tbsp (15 g) of one of the following, chopped: lemon verbena, lemon balm, lemon thyme, lemon basil, lemon catnip, or lemon zest. Also add salt and pepper to taste, if desired.

steps.headline: Spoon the mixture into the center of each flower.
steps.description: Depending on the size of the flowers, you’ll likely be able to fit 1-2 tsp (5-10 g) into each flower. Be generous but don’t overstuff the flowers.

steps.headline: Close the flower petals over the filling in the center.
steps.description: Use your fingers to gently lay the flower petals over the cream cheese mixture, then press lightly to hold them in place. Don’t try to conceal the entire filling with the petals. If you prefer to leave the flower petals more open, that’s fine as well. Just press them enough to help keep the filling in place.

steps.headline: Plate and serve the stuffed flowers right away.
steps.description: Lay the cleaned and dried nasturtium leaves on the serving plate, then array the stuffed flower petals on top. Make it look like an edible bouquet! Serve and eat the stuffed flowers right away. You can chill them for another 1-2 hours if necessary, but the flowers and leaves will start to wilt.

steps.headline: Harvest 0.5 c (60 g) of green nasturtium seed pods.
steps.description: Look for the seed pods attached to the stems underneath the nasturtium foliage, growing in groups of 3. They’re round, green, and about 0.33 in (8.4 mm) in diameter. Avoid seed pods that are yellowish or brownish, as these have an unpleasant flavor and texture. The seed pods start appearing in late summer in many climate zones.

steps.headline: Boil 8  fl oz (240 ml) of salted water in a small pot.
steps.description: Stir in 2 tbsp (30 g) of salt, add a lid, and turn off the heat as soon as the water comes to a boil.

steps.headline: Add the seeds and then the boiling salt water to a screw-top glass jar.
steps.description: Put the seeds in the bottom of a 16  fl oz (470 ml) jar while the water is coming to a boil. Right after turning off the heat, carefully pour the salted water into the jar. Screw the lid on tightly.

steps.headline: Let the seeds soak in the sealed jar of water for 3 days.
steps.description: Keep the jar at room temperature and out of direct sunlight, such as in a kitchen cabinet or pantry. The seeds will soften during this soaking process.

steps.headline: Drain the seed pods after they’re done soaking in the jar.
steps.description: Pour the contents of the jar into a strainer, then pour the seeds right back into the jar. They'll be softer and a little larger after soaking in the water for 3 days.

steps.headline: Boil vinegar, sugar, bay leaves, and thyme in a small pot.
steps.description: Add 6  fl oz (180 ml) of white wine vinegar, 2 tsp (10 g) of sugar, 2 fresh bay leaves (or 1 dried leaf), and 2 sprigs of thyme that are each 3 in (7.6 cm) in length. Give everything a quick stir, put a lid on the pot, and bring the mixture to a boil.

steps.headline: Pour the boiling mixture into the seed pod jar.
steps.description: As soon as the mixture starts to boil, remove the pot from the heat and carefully pour it into the jar and over the softened seed pods. Allow the jar to cool to room temperature with the lid off. It may take 10-15 minutes for the jar to cool.

steps.headline: Seal the jar and refrigerate it for 3 days before using the seed pods.
steps.description: Screw the lid back on the jar and create a long-term spot for it in the fridge. You can start using the pickled seed pods after 3 days, but store them in the refrigerator so you can keep using them for up to 6 months. Make sure the seed pods remain covered by the liquid in the jar so they don’t dry out or spoil.You can use these pickled nasturtium seed pods in any dish that calls for capers, such as chicken piccata.
